author: Nicole
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2018
review_content: I've always preferred cold drinks to hot ones so imagine my joy when companies started selling pre-made cold-brew coffee in the grocery store. At about $7 per bottle though, it was costing me more to buy it that way rather than brewing my own hot coffee and adding ice. It wasn't until I was perusing YouTube and saw one of my favorite YT'ers pouring her own cold-brew out of a refrigerated container. I immediately toggled to Amazon in a search for one similar and I found this product. After comparing prices and reviews, I decided to give this one a try. 3 weeks and several brews later here are my takeaways:Pros: Easy to clean and use, coffee tastes great, not going back to buying pre-made!Cons: Durability seems fragile as the soft foamy plastic on the handle is coming up already, it will leak if you don't screw the lid on tight so beware, since it has to brew laying down it takes up more space in my small fridge than I'd likeOverall though, it's a much cheaper alternative to pre made cold brews and you can control the strength and taste of your coffee by selecting the brand/grounds/roast you want and by adding more or less ground to the filter.Special Note: I read through a lot of reviews and it seems the main issue most people had was the coffee grounds seeping into the liquid. It appears from reading the replies from the manufacturer and by my own experience with this, that they have created a smaller mesh filter and have stopped shipping the product with the old style. The new style is so good that I'm using fine ground coffee and have had NO grounds in my end product. So please disregard older comments about this issue if you're ordering this for the first time.Another main issue is about the leaking but if you screw the top on securely and shake any excess out into a sink before placing it back into the fridge that will prevent leakage. For just in case, it's good to have a paper towel under your brewer when placed on its side.
title: Easy and Cheap Way To Make Cold-Brew Coffee

author: Reviewer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2019
review_content: First off, due to the weight and volume that the coffee grounds add, you do not yield 2 quarts of coffee. I make my coffee on the weekend so that I don't have to deal with it on weekdays when I'm busy getting ready for work. I thought 2 quarts would give me 4 servings (I drink at least 2 cups of black coffee in the morning) but it only gives me about 3 servings total.Secondly, there is no fill line indicated anywhere on the pitcher so you'd have to eyeball how much water you are putting in (unless you pre-measure your water, which is an extra annoying step I don't want or need). The instructions say you pour water up to 3/4 of the bottle (before coffee) but that depends on how much coffee you have in the filter because once the coffee grounds absorb water, of course they add volume to the total. So you end up with more or less water than you want and have to adjust it accordingly, which means you have to screw and unscrew the filter and pull it out or tilt the filter so you can pour your water.  More annoying additional step.  You can draw a line with a sharpie on the bottle but that's besides the point.  The brewing system needs to be where you put the coffee first and then pour the water over the coffee, without having to mess with the lid, etc., not the other way around.Thirdly, the spout malfunctions every time. It is poorly designed. When you pour your coffee, it ALWAYS drips outside the spout, making a mess, not to mention, wasting my expensive coffee.Fourthly, they claim this is a top rack dishwasher safe. Think about it. In what dishwasher top, could this long pitcher possibly fit vertically? If you lay it flat horizontally, does that clean the inside of the bottle? Of course not. What a stupid claim is this?Lastly, the overall pitcher feels flimsy and has a slight sticky feel (I don't know how to describe this). It certainly does NOT feel like it is a BPA-free material (in comparison with other quality bottles made by Nalgene).Not. At. All impressed whatsoever. Definitely not worth the $.I do not recommend.
title: A lot of flaws

author: Jessica M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2017
review_content: Great cold brew system! We had been putting off getting one for so long. We have a keurig and simply put brewed coffee in the fridge overnight. But as our keurig seems to be dying, it was time to explore other options. I wish we had done it sooner! This system is so easy to use - add your coffee of choice and water, place it in the fridge and wait for the next day. That's it!!  So easy, great tasting coffee that goes far enough for both of us. It easily fits on a shelf or the door. We're considering buying a second because of how much coffee my husband drinks or if we have company.UPDATE:After a couple weeks of use I've noticed 2 flaws to call out. When inserting the filter into the water the grounds sometimes pop up to the top of the filter. This causes the grounds to get stuck and not submerge fully into the water to brew properly. I'm not terribly picky and haven't noticed a huge difference in taste or quality. The fix is easy - insert the filter into the water slowly and if needed tap the filter firmly on the side of the carafe. With a firm tap the grounds should fall to the bottom of the filter.Also, when you insert the grounds into the carafe and twist shut it will push water out if you’ve overfilled it which some reviewers have identified as “leaking”. Simple solution is to screw on the top and tip it over the sink to pour out any excess water. Once that’s done I haven’t had any problems with leaking.Given that these issues are easily fixed, have become 2-3 extra seconds of my routine, and there is no noticeable difference in taste/quality, I'm leaving my rating as 5 stars.
title: Should've bought it sooner!

author: LiliBelle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2020
review_content: This Takeya cold brew coffee jug is wonderful! I know a lot of people use Mason jars, however, I wanted something easier to grab from the fridge and more lightweight (and cheaper!). I have used Takeya products before and have been impressed with their durability as well as the easiness of cleaning them. This cold brew jug has only 4 pieces; the jug, the handle, the lid, and the coffee filter. The coffee filter has an extremely fine mesh and it has not let through even the finest of coffee grounds. It is really easy to clean! The filter, after filling it with your favorite coffee (I find non-flavored coffee to taste best during the cold brew process) then screws into the lid. After you have filled up the jug about 85% of the way with filter water, you place the filter (already attached to the lid) into the water filled jug and screw it on! The coffee will have a great flavor within 8 hours, however, it is most potent by 24hrs and stays fresh up to 72hrs in my opinion. Remember, you are brewing a coffee concentrate as about 1 cup of grounds are used to brew. Mix with 2 parts water or you will... well, be like me that didn't read the directions and was up until 3am with a caffeine high, lol. Overall, I am really pleased with this purchase!If you found this review and pictures helpful in making a decision regarding purchasing this item, please let me know below :)

author: Doug
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2017
review_content: I read the reviews carefully before ordering this item and since we enjoy strong coffee was concerned we might be disappointed, we were not. author: Daniel Davis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2020
review_content: So I have both the 1 quart and 2 quart versions of this. At first I used the instructions with the amount to tablespoons for each, but found the taste and strength lacking compared to cold brews I would have from ones from coffee shops. After reading on the internet, I got a better understanding on ratios of coffee to water. Here are some things I learned.1) If you grind your own beans, you want it a bit coarse, this will help with extraction and prevent coffee grounds ending up in your brew.2) If you have a measuring scale, this will help to replicate success every time. (they are like $10 on Amazon, I already had one for other food stuff already)3) The makers are 1 quart and 2 quarts, which coverts to approximately - 1 quart = 32 oz = 946 mL - 2 quart = 64 oz = 1892 mL4) Most Cold Brew Ratios say 1 part coffee to 8 parts water (1:8) all the way to 1:4 for stronger concentrates.This is where I have an issue with the Takeya brewer. The included filters are not wide enough to back enough coffee grounds. The filter are the same for both the 1 Quart and 2 Quart sizes, with the 2 quart size having the extension piece. Filling the filter up to the brim, you can fill to just over 100 grams, I got to about 104 grams.- At 104 grams, a 1:8 ratio needs 832 mL of water. At a strong 1:4 ratio, it's 416 mL. Which means a brew would get you approximately 28 oz or 14 oz for a strong brew. For a 1:8 ratio concentrate, that's about 3/4 of the bottle and less than 1/2 for a strong concentrate.- It's even worse for the 2 quart size, even if you fill up the coffee bean into the filter and the extension, you can get about 140 grams or so... but who knows if the beans in the extension are being extracted. At 140 grams a 1/8 ratio is 1,120 mL of water, and 1:4 ratio is 560 mL. At 1:8 ratio concentrate, you get about half the capacity of the bottle, but to let it brew overnight, you have to leave if on its side in order for water to be in contact with the coffee, which it barely covers and is impossible with the 1:4 ratio.With the proper ratio, you get a great tasting and strong cold brew to your preference. The issue is the size of the filter and amount of coffee you can fit in it. The 1 quart version is usable, especially at a 1:8 ratio, but the 2 quart version is not really usable because you can't utilize enough coffee for it. I'm currently using the 1 quart version to brew for now and and the 2 quart to contain my brew to repeat another brew in the 1 quart. I'll continue to use this for now until I find a better option.
title: All about the ratios.

author: LSG
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2019
review_content: My first few attempts at making cold brew were...underwhelming. It wasn't to say that it was bad. It just wasn't the strong concentrate I wanted. For each of the batches, I followed the instructions from the takeya video, as well as the measurement instructions from the cold brew coffee companies I purchased from. And then with a little trial and error, I've been making steady improvements.First problem, cleaning. It warped slightly in the dishwasher, Not enough to be unusable, but enough that it leaks a little when I pour when I'm not careful. The pitcher was too tall to fit on the top rack, and I think having to put it on the bottom was what did it. Since then, I just put in a spot of liquid soap and water, screw the lid on, and shake it clean. Air dry upside down.Second problem, I followed the Bizzy coffee's recommendation of 3:1 water to grounds for a super concentrate. This will work in a French press, but not the Takeya. Three cups of water won't reach the top of the filter, and no more than a cup of grounds will fit in the filter. And if the water can't reach the top of the filter, it can't steep all the coffee, giving you weaker, rather than stronger coffee. Keep to the 4:1 ratio Takeya recommends (4 cups will take it right near the top with the filter in).Third problem, dry grounds. Even following the Takeya recommendation of swishing the filter about, I still had batches where I detached the lid, and the top grounds were dry.  As a result, my concentrate wasn't very...concentrated.And now, my process. I keep to the 4:1 ratio. However, I only put 3 cups into the pitcher. After putting in my cup of grounds, I slowly and carefully pour the last cup of water over the grounds, letting it trickle through the filter. This is my way of making sure all the grounds are saturated for maximum flavor. When I lower the filter into the pitcher, I'll even top it off with just a little more water to make sure it reaches the absolute top of the filter. I brew it in the refrigerator for 36 hours, doing the little filter swish 2-3 times. Even when the coffee company recommends room temperature brewing, I prefer it this way. Room temperature may be shorter, but colder makes it sweeter and smoother in my opinion.*edit* I should add that I couldn't tell you exactly how concentrated it is. I pour the concentrate over ice then add cold water until it's the shade of deep translucent brown that I personally like, and top off with unsweetened almond milk, which I believe is close to a 3:1 concentrate.

author: Bob F.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2020
review_content: Trying to recreate the coffee shop cold brew? This unit will do it, if you do it right.I bought my 1qt on December 17, 2018, no issues so far. I thought the filter screen might be the first thing to go, but it and the carafe have held up to countless hand washings/rinsings just fine, never in the dishwasher.Here's what you need to know. The coffee shop cold brew you love is probably brewed in a Toddy. The thing about a Toddy, as well as most cold brewers, is you are brewing a concentrate, to be diluted with water at serving. If you go to Toddy's website and read their instruction book, they give you their recommended brew recipe, but more importantly they give you the recommended ratio to dilute the concentrate with water, for serving.If you extrapolate the Toddy "as served" data, here's the recipe you want with this 1qt brewer.1. Weight out 100 grams of dark roast, coarse grind coffee. If you don't have a kitchen scale, buy one.2. Stand the filter in the carafe. Spoon in 1/2 your coffee into the filter (I use a small funnel), then drizzle the coffee grounds with 1 regular size (16.9 fl.oz./500ml bottled water. Spread the water around, as we're trying to eliminate dry grounds.3. Spoon in the remaining 1/2 of your coffee grounds into the filter, then drizzle the coffee grounds with another  regular size (16.9 fl.oz./500ml bottled water. Do this step slowly to let the wet grounds settle without overflowing the top of the filter. In both Step 2 & 3 we are trying to insure there are no dry grounds.4. VERY IMPORTANT: Once the 100g coffee and 1000ml bottled water are in, slightly lift the filter out of the carafe and screw it into the top lid. The filter has a threaded top, and the lid is threaded inside to accommodate it. Screw it in tightly, as this keeps grounds from overflowing into the carafe reservoir.5. Screw this assembly tightly into the carafe, then back off 1/2 to 1 full turn to allow the brew to de-gas for 5 minutes. After the 5 minutes, screw lid on tight and let brewer sit on counter top 18-24hrs. Do not refrigerate yet.6. When brewing is complete, remove lid and unscrew filter for cleaning. With the filter out, the carafe will be 2/3 full of concentrate.7. Add one more 16.9 Fl. oz/500ml bottle water, stirring it in to the concentrate. It will almost overflow, but it will not spill. Serve over ice, or refrigerate carafe for later.8. Dump grounds and rinse filter, let dry on paper towel on counter top.The above ratio of 100g coffee to 1500ml total bottled water gives you almost the exact "as served" ratio as Toddy recommends. The above ratio is actually slightly stronger than the Toddy brew, but were talking a negligible 2 decimal points difference. Short story: 100g coffee to 3 500ml bottled waters. Delicious.Enjoy.
title: Works great, if you use the correct recipe.

author: Bendy (Ben and Randy)
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2017
review_content: We've been hearing over and over again on how amazing cold brew is, how it's life changing, and how you'll never go back to normal coffee. While the last part is definitely not true, the former two are.Let's be honest here... we're lazy sometimes. We've been using a Keurig for years because ... well ... it's convenient. It's also wasteful as heck. Yes there are a few places that offer recyclable K-Cups, most are not recyclable at all. This means they're all being tossed into landfills cup after cup of coffee.We've had a bag of ground coffee in our fridge since Christmas. We just don't brew coffee normally because, like I said, we're lazy. Plus it's summertime, so who wants HOT coffee? Certainly not us! We decided to get in on this "cold brew" craze. It's been love at first steep.The way you use this contraption is to fill the clear portion of the container MOST of the way (I leave ~1/2 an inch from the top) with FILTERED WATER. We use the water from our fridge b/c it's the best we have. The instructions state the amount of coffee you should use in terms of TABLESPOONS, however by the time you convert it out, it ends up being a CUP of coffee grounds. I'm bad at counting, especially when it's something boring like 16 tablespoons, so we decided to make a paper funnel and pour the cup in all at once. Screw all the pieces together, and give it a good shake. The instructions don't say this specifically, however about halfway through I give it another quick few shakes, which changes the clarity considerably. After 12-24 hours, pour the brew into a container, and dilute with another liter of water. This is important because what comes out of the coffee maker is a CONCENTRATE. Because of this, you wouldn't want to drink it straight.The flavor of the coffee is pronounced, but not overwhelming. It's not bitter at all. My parents go the same coffee as I did and their reaction was, "It was just OK." The cold brew made it amazing. We keep our cold brew in a plastic jug after brewing (the ones most ppl use for KoolAid) and shake it up. Typically this sort of thing stays good for about a week, so we should be good for a while.The only problem I have with this is the filter portion is kind of narrow, so it's difficult to get a *good* clean for it. Granted you can rinse it out really really well, but giving a scrub without specialized equipment isn't possible. I would have also preferred glass instead of plastic, because I feel like less flavor will seep into the plastic for a later time/date. The rubber on the handle is ... awkward. It almost looks like it can/should come off, but at the same time you can tell if you do remove it, you'll likely never get it back on.
title: GREAT tasting coffee, wish filter area was a *touch* wider

author: Nick
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2020
review_content: 1. Buy this for cold brewing coffee if you love lazy convenience.2. There should be a glass option, but I understand the cost could vary.3. Coffee stays fresh and, as per cold brewing, dramatically less acidic equaling healthier coffee.How do you use this?You simply fill the coffee grounds holder with your favorite coffee (I like Bulletproof because it's clean & imo trusted, but any ground coffee will work), fill the jug with water, screw on the lid to the coffee grounds holder, and then screw on the two jug and lid so that it's airtight. At this point, it's advised to put your coffee in the fridge for 8+ hours. From my experience and preference, 8 hours is perfect, but feel free to experiment - you can tell from the color of the water where the state of the coffee is from a little bit of hour by hour observation :).For non-chilled coffee, you don't have to leave it in the fridge over night - theoretically this could speed up the dissolution of the coffee extract into the water.Overall, no point in not picking this up due to it's price and quality if you cold brew or know someone who cold brews (as a gift.)I got the 1 Quart, which gives me about 6 cups of coffee when filled fully. Pro tip: don't fill the water all the way to the brim, but rather leave about one inch to account for the volume taken by the lid. I'll probably end up getting the 2 Quart just because it would be nice to have when people are over.I highly recommend you transition to cold brewing your coffee over acidifying your gut, just for your own health <3

author: MaudMan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2019
review_content: This cold brew coffee maker is just about perfect. I kinda wish it was glass, but BPA-free plastic is OK too I guess. :)  The coffee maker works exactly as advertised and makes the best tasting cold-brew coffee! Of course it helps if you buy organic whole bean coffee and grind your own fresh, but that's a another topic. I read a few reviews from others saying the grounds tend to float to the top of the filter basket and stick to the lid. Well, I found if I followed the direction, I did not have that problem at all. The instructions that came with mine said to screw the lid/filter basket on the top, shake the entire thing, and store in the fridge ON ITS SIDE.  Then every so often, take it out, loosen the lid and twist back and forth a bit. Then tighten the lid again, and put back in fridge on its side.  I did exactly that, the pitcher never leaked a single drop, there wasn't a single coffee ground in my brew, and it tastes absolutely amazing.I would have given a perfect 5-stars, but there are a couple very minor complaints.  I already mentioned wishing it was glass. Aside from that, the way the spout is designed causes it to drip on the counter no matter how I try to pour it. No biggie.  And the way the plastic threads are designed on the filter basket and lid are a little cheesy and hard to get them to screw together. They tend to cross thread and go crooked very easily. It takes a few tries to get it right. I got the 2-quart model, so my filter basket has the extra little extension piece, which doubles the trouble when trying to screw all of it together. However, once you get the threads lined up right, it seems to screw together tight enough to not let any grounds into your brew -- and THAT is the important part.Anyway, I highly recommend this cold brew coffee maker to anyone looking for one. I'm thinking of buying another one so I can have a fresh batch ready all the time.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2019
review_content: I bought several of these and even gave some away as gifts to folks. I assumed that getting coffee grinds in your cold brew coffee was normal. Sometimes I'll have as much as a quarter of an inch of coffee grinds settled at the bottom of my Takeya cold brew container, so I have to be careful to pour it very slowly so as to not disturb the settled grinds. I'm much happier with the "The Original Cold Brew on Tap by Willow & Everett" gallon-sized cold brew container that I recently got; it has a very fine metal mesh that i couldn't get the coffee grinds to go through no matter how much water I poured onto the coffee grinds. review_content: I bought this because it says that "It produces 8 servings of smooth cold brew with any type of coffee grounds and is less acidic than traditional coffee brewing." author: TMB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2020
review_content: Purchased my 1st Takeya Deluxe Cold Brew Iced Coffee Maker (1-Quart model) early in 2018 and it is still going strong with my year-round use of it. Both products contain 4 mesh bags of coffee grounds and both recommend using 2 mesh bags to brew 48 oz of cold-brewed coffee.  I use one mesh bag per quart (33.3 fluid oz) of cold-brewed coffee I am making - carefully putting the self-contained mesh bag into the strainer & filling the container with cold water.  I chose to let it steep in the refrigerator for 24-hours before using it.  I then carefully remove the mesh bag from the strainer for disposal and hand-wash the unit (even though it is top-rack dishwasher safe).

author: SeaSpyder
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2021
review_content: I've read several less-than-glowing reviews, and I don't get it. If you want something fancier, with buttons and functions and fill lines...this is not the product for you. And that's totally cool!. If you like glass and precise measurements, there are a ton of cold brewers that will fit the bill. However, if you're more like me, and are OK eyeballing the amount of coffee you put in and don't mind spending an extra 20 seconds slowly pouring a little water through the grounds to get them completely wet before screwing the filter to the lid and then filling the pitcher the rest of the way up with water and screwing the lid onto the pitcher (by the way - it took me longer to type that sentence than it takes to perform those tasks) you're in the right place. I add course ground coffee until the filter is about 3/4 full, and leave on the counter to steep for 48-ish hours, during which time I give it a good shake whenever the mood strikes. The grounds need space to absorb, expand and move a bit during the shaking process - so if you're packing the filter to the brim, you should not expect a tasty result. Since I steep for 2 days, the resulting brew is concentrated enough that I can top the pitcher off with additional water resulting in a full quart of cold brew that is to my liking. It took me a few tries to get my approach down pat, but I like figuring stuff out so that's part of the fun for me. As mentioned by other reviewers, and if I look reallllly hard, I can see little lines in the clear part of the pitcher that look like hairline cracks, but I haven't experienced any leakage. Bottom line is, this pitcher is easy to clean by hand and small enough to fit in the door of my fridge. I've had this for nearly 2 years, make 1-2 batches per week and we're still going strong. Definitely one of my best Amazon purchases to date.

author: Le Pan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2020
review_content: I do like this pitcher don't get me wrong but it's far from perfect and I'm not trying to nitpick. author: Linda B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2021
review_content: I think this product is GREAT! I read the older reviews and the manufacturer must have worked out all the kinks as I have not had any of the issues mentioned in 3 years. author: Denys
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
review_content: I'm a cold brew aficionado.  I have tried several products to make my own cold brew rather than getting store-bought cold brew and they have all failed and have been returned.  Until now.  I have had the large Takeya cold brew maker for less than two weeks, but I can tell you, this one is a keeper.  I have already made about 10 batches and I'm now having fun trying different coffees.  Right now, I am trying 2 blends and comparing.My process is simple, I fill up the pot with filtered water to about an inch from the bottom of the white rim. I load up the filter with coffee ground coarse to the top of the filter.  I attach the extension and then the lid, and slowly dunk the filter in the water.  I tighten everything and swirl the water around for a minute or two to wet the coffee.  Don't shake too hard or tip it around, well, unless you like grounds in your coffee.I leave the Takeya on the counter for the day, swirling it one in a while.  At night, I place it in the refrigerator and the next morning I transfer to cold brew to another jar, clean up the Takeya and either make another batch right away or just put it away until the next time.  Usually, I start another batch because it doesn't last long.The clean up is pretty quick.  I dump most of the grounds directly in the garbage.  I know some people use the grounds for other purposes, I don't, but I also don't put them in the garbage disposal.  I then clean and dry all the parts with soap and water, rinse, dry and assemble.My observations:1- The extension is sometimes finicky to connect to the filter.2- I'm not sure how sturdy the actual filter fabric is and I treat it very cautiously.  Thankfully, it's not an expensive unit and it's made of plastic so it shouldn't shatter.3- Sometimes find a small amount of residue at the bottom, but since I've only been swirling and not shaking, that seems to have mostly gone away.  I have had batches with no residue whatsoever.  Just gotta be diligent.4- It's actually pretty neat to see the coffee permeate the water over a few hours.  I go for about 22-24 hours because I really like my coffee.Highly recommended.  Make sure you start with good water and coarse coffee.
title: Finally, a device that makes great cold brew

author: Debbie C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2019
review_content: I'm new to cold brewing coffee. I needed to switch or I would have to stop drinking coffee all together and I was told cold brew was less acidic and should help. AND IT DID. But on to the product. I needed something easy, inexpensive, and that I had a low chance of ruining. This fit all of those. I was nervous about trying cold brew on my own but this made it easy breezy. I bought my regular coffee that's already ground and have had zero issues with grounds in my coffee. I put in the 14 tbsps that was recommended and put it in the fridge. 12 hours later, done. I leave it in 2 days max with no problem. I use medium roast because I have to and I was afraid it would be too weak and honesty it wasn't. I put a dash of creamer and ice and I'm good to go.After I put the coffee grounds in I pour at least one cup of water through the filter (It was a suggestion I saw from another review and it's great in wetting all the grounds. I shake it a bit every so often when I go into the fridge.I make sure to twist it close softly. I haven't found a way to not make the filter loosen when I go too fast. I don't think it'll drop in but I don't want to take any chances.Also there is no need to close it too tight. You can feel the click of it when its align.I thought I would be able to pour coffee without taking the lid off if the filter wasn't on but I can't..Not a big deal for me though.My only regret is not getting the bigger one. If i had known...if only. LOL. So that will be a definite purchase in the future.
title: Perfect

author: mbi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review_content: I used to live in the PNW where there was a coffee stand darn near every 4 or 5 blocks, so the coffee had to be good to be competitive.  Around here,  it's hard to come by. I started just buying the cold brew bottles and putting them into my reusable cups. I would get frustrated because they would be sold out time to time,  so i would have to buy 4-5 (i drink 2 cups of hot in the morning fresh ground,  1 cup of cold in the afternoon when it's hot,  and finish off the day with a decaffeinated hibiscus blend hot tea). At roughly 5/ bottle,  each bottle lasting 2 days,  that's roughly 2.50 a day. That's quite a lot when you add up how many hot months there are down south (basically April to part of November depending on the year and mothers nature). You can see how this adds up quickly, not to mention the plastic waste, for something that is OK. I have my own espresso maker (which i do make amazing coffee might i add), so why not this. I researched several.  I didn't want to spend a lot on something that i wouldn't really dedicate myself to,  and this fit the price.  Honestly,  I wish I had purchased the bigger one available,  but I was holding myself accountable.  When i first opened it,  it felt cheap to me.  I rolled my eyes, and figured you get what you pay for.  That was not the case here at all. The center holder for coffee was measured perfectly and even stands straight to easily fill.  Super easy to take apart and clean. Simple sleek design.  No slip handle grip.  Simple twist top. Great pour spout. I am impressed by this.  It takes roughly 1/4 of a standard sized bag of coffee, so roughly 2.50 to fill plus water,  shake,  refrigerate, and wait.  I pour into a double walled Insulated Stainless steel cup with a straw roughly 1/2 full and the rest with water.  I get to use my preferred beans (if using whole bean, grind as if you are making for a standard drip coffee pot). Make sure you shake it before pouring to fully mix.  This makes roughly 4 cups. Now that 2.50 a day has been changed to a more palatable 0.675 a day.  I recommend using a blonde coffee bean,  as a dark bean can be a shock for some to drink black.  Love this cold brew coffee system.- The Wife
title: Enjoying the best cold coffee and saving money

author: Aldee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2021
review_content: I don't know how good is a good outcome when it comes to brewing cold brew. All I know is that this brewing pitcher is an easy buy when making a cold brew. I had to research of course, and I ended up with this because of the simplicity and the cost to buy. I have yet to still find a very good brewing time for my coffee and different coffees have different characteristics and reaction to brewing management. Like with aeropress, I am still experimenting, though I have quit that method for quite a while now. I would like to get back with the aeropress some of these days. You can view cold brew as a sort of meal prep; you'll have coffee for days before brewing another one, unless you're in love, or need a lot of coffee. Whereas the aeropress, even though it's quick, it still can be served in a relaxing manner if that is your sort of thing, I'm for sure not like that every day as some days you want to rush the start of the day like there's no tomorrow lol.Now with my cold brew, a day and a half gives me a good brew, usually, with the coffee container almost full and the water about an inch to the brim(the visible, not the threaded area). I like it when I store it at room temperature as it gives me the general cold brew taste. I can't remember trying it in the fridge, but I heard you just have to give an extra day or hours. And I've mentioned, you can have mugs of the brew for days and I am not joking, this thing does store a good amount, granted, you do dilute the concentrate with water. For that, I commend this item for its effectiveness. There might be better products out there, but I am happy with this brewing pitcher.
title: When you just want to make some cold brew

author: Michelle in NH
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2020
review_content: The only thing I really like about this brewer is that it makes the perfect amount of cold brew for me, for on day. I drink two 32 ounce tumblers of cold brew each day, and my son adds a couple ounces to chocolate milk in the AM, so we always had the perfect amount.That said, just about else was a con.Everything is plastic, with 3 separate parts that need to twist together. The filter attaches to a plastic collar, which attaches to the lid. Getting these pieces lined up is an infuriating process.Getting the amount of water right for your grinds is total guesswork, which is also infuriating. A bit too much and as you twist down the cap, it will overflow. Too little, and you won't cover the grounds once they saturate. You will absolutely need to top off the water level about 30 minutes after the initial preparation. This involves no only dealing with lining up the threads again, but hoping you don't add to much water. A complete and total pain in the butt.I absolutely do not recommend this brewer.
title: Difficult to assemble, hard to get the amount of water correct.

author: Heather Riddles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2020
review_content: Not going to lie, I was pretty upset when this item arrived because I viewed it as 4 different overly-priced plastic pieces. I ordered the 2L size, not because I have multiple people drinking coffee with me, but because I drink 12 to 16 ounces of cold brew every morning. It’s pretty efficient at keeping up with my cold brew intake. After a couple weeks of using this pitcher, I realized it was not the plastic that you are paying for with this item. You’re paying for the design. It’s very sleek and cool-looking in your fridge, yes, but in addition it keeps the coffee grinds out of your brew completely and making the most delicious cold brew I’ve ever had. Before the quarantine, I would purchase a cold brew from Starbucks every morning. Now I enjoy my own cold brew more than Starbucks cold brew. I have full control of the strength and flavor, I can even get creative and combine different coffee grounds to make my own brew. My only complaint is the filter piece is difficult to clean. I have tiny hands and cannot reach down in there with normal hand-washing methods. The other plastic pieces are pretty easy to clean, I can even fit my entire arm into the pitcher section to clean it with a soft sponge. After purchasing a baby-bottle brush I am now able to clean every nook and cranny of the filter, so I have no more complaints other than that I had to spend more money on a specialty cleaning brush to clean the filter.
title: Smart design, great taste, hard to clean

author: Vinny
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2021
review_content: This is an excellent, and extremely well-designed and well-crafted, cold coffee brewer. I now own two of them in the 2 quart model, and will soon be ordering one of the one-gallon versons as well.This is an extremely well-designed cold coffee brewer, with all of the practical features that make it a real joy to use. It was obviously designed by professionals, and for use by professionals. The very best features are that it has been designed so that with a twist of the lid/cap, the lid can be totally sealed and rendered completely watertight and airtight, meaning that the device can easily be shaken, swirled or inverted during brewing/steeping without any danger of leaks or splashes, and without letting any air in.Best of all, when the lid is sealed, the brewer can be stored in the fridge (or  elsewhere) without danger of accidental spills, and without absorbing any stray food odors from the fridge air. Even  better, the absolutely airtight and watretight seal of the lid, when closed, means that the cold coffee may be brewed while the device is lying on its side, which is something that the manufacturer recommends.One more incrediblly helpful design feature: the center immersible filter screen cylinder has been designed to hold all coffee grounds BENEATH the surface of the liquid during brewing/steeping, thus insuring complete immersion of the grounds (many other brands of cold brew coffee maker do not do this, thus creating a recipe for disaster!).Amazing product! I love it!
title: Excellent! Best of the Lot! Stands Heads & Shoulders Above Most of the Competitors!

author: Rene Tenazas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2021
review_content: This product works.  However, you need to add water to the container without any marker to guide you.  If you put too much water, it may overflow, since adding the coffee causes some of the water to be displaced.  If you put too little water, some of the coffee may not be in contact with the water and are essentially wasted.  It is not easy to add more water, once you put the filter with coffee into the container.  It should be simple for the manufacturer to just add a line on the clear container, to guide users.It’s easy to clean, but the filter feels a little flimsy.  I have since seen some cold brewers with stainless steel filters.  Those should be sturdier, but I am not sure they are as easy to clean.
title: A little difficult to use

author: Robin H
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2020
review_content: I live in California and once late Spring/Summer hit it’s time to switch to cold brew.  I have had no complaints about this cold brew coffee maker yet.  Well, except that cleaning the grounds out isn’t the most enjoyable experience, but if someone can point me to a cold brew coffee maker where cleaning the grounds out isn’t a slight pain let me know.  I’m not talking about the single use bags.  The one issue I do have, and this applies to both Takeya pitchers I have, is that sometimes the lids won’t seat perfectly and if you invert it a little liquid will come out.  I only do this over the sink, and don’t quite trust them enough to store them horizontally in my fridge.  A nice plus that if you don’t want to make cold brew, remove the filter and you have a perfectly good 1 quart pitcher.
title: Makes an Alright Cup of Cold Brew

author: Sam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2021
review_content: I’ve had many cold brew makers: a great OXO one that inevitably clogs beyond use, a glass ball jar one thats way too heavy to reliably pick up without dropping it at 6am, and now this plastic garbage. I thought i might save myself some headache but nope, this thing blows.First off, in the instructions say to shake the pitcher to get all the grounds wet. Shaking your grounds is a perfect recipe for cold brew to comes out grimy and gross. But unfortunately, this thing is so badly designed that if you dont shake enough, a solid half of your grounds remain dry 24 hours later. I woke up this morning to the world’s weakest coffee despite trying to shake the pitcher a few times without destroying the brew. It seems shaking is a VITAL aspect of this pitcher, but they dont bother explaining how much or aggressively? The mesh is WAY too thick and basically makes sure the water and grounds NEVER mingle (other than of course the water that gets stuck inside the mesh and is impossible to drain out) and ensures you wake up to the world’s weakest and most bland brew on earth.TLDR: Instructions say to shake your grounds in the pitcher, giant red flag, instructions are zero help. Even letting it brew a full 24 hours outside the fridge produces the world’s weakest coffee

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2018
review_content: Extremely disappointed in this item. I bought this after being at a friend’s who had this exact model and loved it. Really bummed because I was looking forward to being able to use this product daily and be able to store it upright or on its side.
title: Leaks!!!

author: Mn mom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2020
review_content: Pluses: appears to be non-breakable.Dishwasher safe (fortunately I can put plastic items on my bottom rack, because there is no way it would fit on top.)Nice look and size,good filter**EXCEPT CLEANINGMinuses: RIDICULOUS design!! You are supposed to fill the coffee filter, then screw into the two-part cover. Therefore, you cannot pour water through the coffee grounds. This leads to all of the coffee floating to the top of the device. I instead manually hold the filter in place, then pour in the water, finally screwing onto the two piece lid. The design of my (sadly broken) glass carafe was superior. But I won't buy glass again.Also the O-ring system is inconvenient. title: Plusses and minuses,

author: Kiana
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2020
review_content: I prefer cold coffee most times, but brewing hot and then icing wasn't giving me the right flavor profile. I am in love with this cold brew maker already!I used 28 tablespoons, filled with cold filtered water 3/4 full and let it go for 24 hours on its side. It does not leak at all. At around 12 hours, I picked it up to shake and swirl, and noticed the coffee grounds had absorbed a fair bit of water which I expected. I opened it up and topped it off with more fresh water. At 24 hours I was rewarded with a deep black pitcher full of cold brew. The flavor is fantastic, the coffee is smooth and strong (this will of course, depend on your coffee of choosing and grind size).A few notes:- It is easy to take apart and clean- It does indeed fit in the door of my fridge- The 2qt model suggests 28-32 tablespoons. At 28 tablespoons, the level of the grounds when dry is higher than the filter itself, nearly up into the extender which is why I stopped there. I do not know if I would ever use more than 28 for fear of wasting coffee.- Pour spout does not drip while in use. It opens about 1 full turn to pour coffee, you can continue to open it but past that point you are actually unscrewing the entire lid/filter.- You do need to remove the filter/grounds when the brewing process is done so it does not become bitter. Overall, very happy with it, will likely update after a while once I determine it's longevity after repeated uses.
title: Easy to use for strong, smooth cold brew

author: Bret
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2020
review_content: The took the one-quart version of the filter and screwed on a solid piece of plastic to make a crappy extension -- but  there's no filter on the top half and no way for the extra coffee to steep.  PLUS the cloth filters on these plug quickly with the coffee oils.  Stainless steel mesh is SO MUCH BETTER.  This is really crappy execution.
title: Two-quart version is lame

author: EHop
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2020
review_content: This is a super handy device for cold brew! I was buying the bottled kind in the grocery store for about $5 a bottle. Now I can make it at home!I don’t like very strong coffee so I’ve started putting about a quarter of a cup of grounds in the inner compartment and fill the water about 3/4 of the way full. Then shake it up really vigorously and let it set over night. For a lighter brew, don’t let it brew as long. The next morning, dump the grounds in the trash and replace the lid.Even after it has brewed, it usually still needs to be cut with some water and creamer for me.But I can’t say enough great things about this product! It’s just a balance to figure out the right ratio of grounds to water to brew time.
title: This makes very concentrated coffee! Be sure you water down!

author: Sailthenet
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2021
review_content: This is a very easy to use, and clean, cold brew maker. I only wish they made a larger unit that made more coffee each time.This unit is simple: put your ground coffee in the inside container, which is removable for adding grounds, and for cleaning. Add water to the carafe to the proper level (if you add too much water and insert the filter/grounds unit, the water overflows - you won’t do that twice) and screw the grounds containing filter unit into the lid of the carafe.Put the filter unit into the carafe containing water. Screw tight the lid. Shake the carafe and watch the coffee and water mix. Put the unit in the refer. Shake it a couple of times during the next 24 hours (you don’t HAVE to brew for 24 hours, but you will get the best flavor that way), unscrew the top half a turn to dispense coffee.I’ve read online reviews of cold brew equipment, and this item has all the features the highest rated units had. The flavor of the cold brew is very good. No bitterness, very smooth.This does create a “cold brew concentrate”, so you can add about 25% more water to the concentrate when you serve the brew. Individual tastes may allow adding more water the concentrate.
title: Excellent brewer. Great coffee, easy to use

author: Mr. Daniel T. Ichiyama
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2020
review_content: TL;DR: it's physically impossible to immerse enough grounds in the water to make a "concentrate".  if you just want cold brew, this works fine.  If you want concentrate, invest in something else.I bought this thinking that I would be able to make my own cold brew concentrate to add water or milk to and make my own drinks the way I like them.  The way it's written up on Amazon and in the instruction manual makes me think that this is possible. However...The way the one quart is designed, I doubt this was ever possible.  Most folks recommend a ratio of about 15-20g of coffee for every 100ml of water.  The filter only holds at most 120g of coffee, which means 800ml of water, producing a low concentrate of 15:100.  Fine, I could like with that. BUT this amount of water is not enough to fill up the container, and so it's impossible to immerse all of the grounds in the water at once, even when placed horizontally.  Major design flaw for coffee concentrate.So, if you want something that'll make a cup of regular cold brewed coffee, this'll work.  But if you're like and you wanted something like the Toddy, get a Toddy.
title: Okay for the price, but somethings are misleading

author: Julie Padula
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2017
review_content: I love this. It's the easiest thing in the world to use and it produces smooth, tasty cold brew coffee.  You just add 14 tsps. of coffee to the filter, then put the filter into the pitcher which is filled 3/4 of the way with cold water, shake it up and put it in the fridge. It suggests 12-24 hours but I've found the coffee tastes the best after 24. I also take it out every so often and shake it up to mix it up a bit.I was so impressed and happy with it, I've now bought this for a friend, and my dad. My only complaint is that I wish the pitcher was bigger because I get maybe 2-3 days out of a full one, so I'm constantly washing and prepping for coffee for the next day. GREAT purchase. I'm enjoying some at work right now!
title: Do it yourself - easiest cold brew in the world!

author: M. Cooper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2017
review_content: No need to spend two or three times this on a cold brew coffee maker - this is easy to use and works really well. (The perceived "lump" in my throat from overnight reflux went away within days.)Just take 4 ounces of course-ground coffee, add 4 cups of water (I do 1 cup of hot water for a "hot bloom" and then add the rest after 30-60 seconds to bring out more flavour), leave for 12-24 hours (shaking occasionally) and you're done.It's easier to buy two, so you can make the next batch when you're running low. The jar has a rubber seal to keep fridge smells out and the coffee aromas in. And everything is dishwasher safe (the jar is fine on the bottom rack).The only challenge can be getting all the coffee into the mouth of the filter. But this is a perfect solution and fits exactly into the top of the filter! https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B000HJ99XS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

author: Beepbeep

author: AR

review_content: I had the same issue as another reviewer, a piece of plastic not removed at production was keeping it from seeling properly. author: Anonymous1
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2020
review_content: Used for both cold brew tea and tea made with boiling water then cooled. Cold brewing the tea did not tend to result in very concentrated tea, and I found myself adding more and more tea to the diffuser. Regular boiling water poured directly into the container worked fantastically for a good concentrated tea which I just popped into the fridge to cool to prepare cold milk tea.Cleaning is a breeze, just unscrew the lid and diffuser then place in the dishwasher. Done multiple times with no issues and performance has not changed after washing.The seal when screwed together properly is tight enough for me to shake the container and invert it several times without leaking. Bonus points for multiple uses as a flavored water maker or coffee brewer.After a few months of use, I would definitely recommend to friend, and I already have.
title: Happy with purchase

author: Maldad89
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2021
review_content: It gets the job done and does it well! Made my first batch yesterday morning and poured myself some today... came out exactly how I would of hoped even with cheaper supermarket coffee (wasn't gonna waste my good stuff experimenting)! Couple key points... since the filter is attached to the top, its not the easiest to pour over your grounds in order to properly stir and "bloom" them. If done correctly this refines the flavor and smoothness of your brew. I get that's a hot coffee deal but it does make a difference for cold brew as well. I added 1 cup of course ground coffee, then ran cold water over them into the container and let it sit for 15 minutes... instead of stirring I bobbed the filter in the water and agitated the grounds before adding the next cup. Repeated the process now with a full container and all grounds associated with the recipe. Brew sat refrigerated for 24 hours before serving. Like I said... it came out great, smooth and a nicely refined taste for it being cheaper coffee. I can't wait to try some better beans next!!
title: Great For Price

author: Theresa C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review_content: I have been using this weekly for several months now and I am SO impressed. I was worried at first because I noticed a lot of reviews that said the mesh doesn't last. However, I've had no problems with the filter or with cleaning it. I wipe it off under gentle running water and it comes away perfectly clean. I also noticed a lot of comments about a significant amount of grounds ending up in the brew, but I haven't had a problem with that either. When recipes tell you to occasionally agitate (or shake) the pitcher, they don't necessarily mean shake it up and down like a shake weight as hard as you can. I shake it back and forth a bit and swirl it around, just enough to keep the grounds in the filter wet. The flavor is so smooth and creamy, I can't imagine not drinking cold brew from now on (with the occasional pour-over; I'm a hot drink person through and through). While it is plastic, it's quite sturdy and the quality feels nice for the price. It also comes with thorough instructions and recipes if you're unsure how to get started.
title: Be gentle with your pitcher; Delicious brews for months to come!

author: Allee Parnell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2021
review_content: I bought this so I could make coffee EASILY at home. The directions in the box are not 100%. I say that because you HAVE to screw the filter into the lid first. You can not just put the filter in the bottle then screw the lid on. (Made that mistake and had coffee grounds everywhere in the coffee because the filter was not sealed) finally watched a video and done it correctly and it worked amazing. No leaks or anything. I left it in the fridge for 12 hours, put ice in a cup, turned the lid twice to open it, poured it in(no leaks) added what I wanted to it, BAM awesome coffee. Really really love this item.
title: Just buy it, you’ll love it

author: JohnnyB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2019
review_content: My wife and I recently had our first child.  My wife never drank coffee because she hated the taste of it.  Well after a couple trips with her co-workers to the local coffee shop my wife became addicted to Ice coffee.  Now, If you have children you will understand what it is like to truly be perpetually tired.  This ice coffee addiction quickly became a $75 a week bill, so much that we were literally added it to our bill spread sheet.  We realized this was a problem so we decided to try a cold brew coffee concentrate from the local Aldi's.  My wife was in love.  The thing with Ice coffee is that it is brewed strong and then cooled with ice.  My wife, not liking the flavor of the coffee, would add an absurd amount of cream and sugar.  Cold brew coffee has a different flavor.  Sorry I am by no means a connoisseur of coffee but I didn't know that until I started doing some research.  Cold brew lacks the bitterness you get from hot brewing the beans.  We fill the 2 quart coffee filter with coffee to the top of the screen part of the filter, add just over 1 1/2 quarts of cold water to the maker, seal it up and lay it on it's side (per instructions) and let it sit for 12 hours.  My wife then mixes it 2 parts coffee to 1 part water and stores it in a glass container.  In the morning she simply pours from the container to her mug and adds a dash of french vanilla creamer.  No sugar.  I have long been a hot coffee drinker, I now drink these cold brews the same way.  10/10 would recommend this product to anyone else.  I am a little concerned with how long the filter will hold up, and the handle does seem a little flimsy if you try to pick the full pitcher up by it.  We have been using it for 2 weeks and it does not leak when on its side in the fridge.  If has lasted for 2 weeks and has already paid for itself.
title: Money Saver

author: Doog
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2021
review_content: This is a great convenience for coffee lovers, even if it's not the absolute best product.The filter works well, only letting a little bit of the finer grinds through. My biggest issue, though, is that there's no good way to squeeze excess water/coffee out of the grounds once you're finished. I've tried leaving the filter in a big cup or mug for a while to let the water drain out to then add back to the jug, but I eventually settled on transferring the grounds to some cheese cloth and wringing it out by hand.Another issue I had is with the instructions. You're instructed to fill the filter/infuser pretty much completely full with grounds, which for the 1 quart jug would make it about a 1:4 ratio of coffee:water, which is a concentrate. But the instructions don't tell you to water it down before drinking. If you like your coffee strong, this is fine enough, but for most people you'll probably want to dilute that concentrate by about 1/2 before drinking. Or as an easier option, just only fill the infuser about halfway, and the coffee straight from the jug should be just right.
title: Easy and convenient, with some caveats

author: Salvatore A. Simeone

author: Carl Hernandez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2020

author: TR
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2021

author: gingersnap

author: Karin

review_content: Because some people have asked, I doubt that it's totally Leak Proof. author: Just MK
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2021
review_content: I’ve purchased 4 of these! Every time they show up in Prime Day, I grab another. They make great gifts for the people in your life who love their cold brew. I’ve been told it was the “perfect gift”, too.My previous method was to soak 1.5 cups coffee grounds (Community Coffee Dark Roast) in 8 cups of water in a pitcher or batter bowl with a lid and a pouring spout. And you can fill the water almost up to the top without overflowing if you insert the lid/coffee filter piece in slowly. Highly recommended!

author: Joso
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2020
review_content: Edit: the bottom part is plastic, it’s cracked and started leaking. Threw it away and bought a glass one. It was good while it lasted, but sadly it didn’t last long. author: Sdem
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2021
review_content: I bought this to make cold brew coffee.I like how easy to use this product is. If you love iced/cold brew you need this!!!

author: VGunz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2019
review_content: I loved this cold brew pitcher.  I have purchased two other brands previously plus this one and this particular one is my favorite.  As far as taste, they are all very similar, however, the material used for this one makes it easier to clean and more versatile.  It holds a good amount, fits nicely in the fridge because it is shorter, and is plastic to prevent breakage.  The other two brands I had were glass and both shattered... not just broke, but shattered into little slivers of glass around my kitchen.  This one is also easy and quick to use.  I usually make it at night and I am exhausted but it is a quick fill up an twist then in the fridge it goes.  I believe I have purchased six total of this pitcher.  I own two myself, and the rest are gifts.  I have owned the first one now for almost two years and it is still in perfect condition even after all the dishwasher runs it has been through.  The filter also is easy to clean/dumping out the coffee grounds.  The grounds don't get stuck in little crevasses like other ones I have had.I have to drink cold brew because the acidic level when brewed using heat irritates my throat, so this little pitcher has been a lifesaver.
title: Easy to clean, fits in fridge without taking up too much space & makes delicious iced coffee.

author: Kristi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2020
review_content: For quarantine I did what everyone else was and decided to try to get healthier and eat right. I naturally love sweeter things, so for my coffee I would always have to add some sugar and cream. I cut back on the cream and changed to a natural 0 calorie sugar. Then I came across a cold brew coffee article about how it's actually naturally sweeter bc boiling coffee grids adds most of the coffee bitter taste. I had always thought of cold brew as tart and too strong that I couldn't tolerate it. This product changed all that (you have to have the right coffee grinds which I love BIZZY smooth). With my first cup I was hooked. This is so easy to clean and use. It really is air tight, once you seal it, you could store this thing upside-down if you so choose. Fill the base with water. Fill the filter piece with coffee. Screw filter on lid and lid on base. Put in fridge. Each brew lasts 6-10 drinks depending on how how many parts water you add that day to get the level strong you want your drink that day. Every morning I wake up to a nice cold brew coffee where I use more parts per water mix (1pt coffee to 3pt water) of the brew and use it as a naturally sweet pre workout caffeine boost.
title: My best quarantine buy yet

author: Jacqueline
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2021
review_content: This cold brew maker is simple to use! I followed the exact instructions and I love my homemade cold brew better than Starbucks now. author: Rachel Perlow
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2021
review_content: It makes decent coffee, but I would not say it makes a coffee concentrate; I'd say it makes a strong iced coffee. You really need to do a very coarse grind with it, otherwise, the filter gets gunked up, and you don't get a good brew. You also don't want to fill it with ground coffee above the part where the filter separates from the center of the tube, and you want to fill the water inside the filter from the top, so it gets saturated. You also want to fill it outside the filter when it is being submerged.
title: Good, but has a learning curve

author: Karen T.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2019
review_content: My first clumsy attempts at cold brew, and I bought this after reading reviews about glass vs plastic. I'm glad I did. It is reasonably priced, easy to use, stays sealed when on its side and makes a good amount for me. I am the only one who drinks coffee in our household, so the large one lasts me about 7-8 days of morning coffee. As I get low, I transfer the coffee to a mason jar so I can run a brew for 48 hours and have a constant supply of coffee.I'm a hot coffee person, so the switch over to cold has not been...easy. Even if I combine hot water with the cold brew it comes out tepid. So, I'm not sure if it's a mind switch to accept the cold coffee in the morning or a taste thing. Considering it's 90 degrees by 11 am during summer, the iced coffee is easier to transition to than if it was in the winter. I do find that the same coffee I used in the coffee maker tastes less biting as a cold brew.i very much like the taste. I like the convenience of the coffee already made. I will see if I stay with it... Beyond that, I really like the plastic container. It's oval, so it lays on it's side very well. If you're making your first foray into cold brew, this is a great starter kit.
title: Easy to use and clean. Stays sealed. The plastic has been sturdy.

author: Ariel Koerber
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2021
review_content: This cold brew coffee pitcher is AWESOME. I can only guess that reviewers who have issues didn’t read the included instruction booklet. Which I admit- I didn’t at first either but was able to remedy the issues I had. Overall if you love cold brew and are looking for a good zero-waste device that you can use over & over this is it!Important things to remember- 2 Cups of COARSE ground coffee. Yes the mesh is fine and I don’t think fine grounds would leak through it, but they will escape when you shake / swirl the pitcher. In the US, prior to COVID you could ground coffee beans in most grocery stores specifically to Coarse or “for French Press.” The only brand I could find in my Kroger store that was coarse ground is Gevalia their Guatemala variety.* to easily add this 2 cups to the infuser the Ball mason jar funnel fits perfectly. Otherwise you’ll have to go spoonful by spoonful- Fill with 7 cups of water BEFORE you put the infuser back in. Some reviewers complain they have to measure the water. But you could do it once and then put a mark on the pitcher to see where you filled it to. It’s an extra step but I don’t think it’s worth taking a star away-Once pitcher is filled with water, twist the infuser into the cap FIRST. Then lower the infuser by the cap into the pitcher. If you don’t twist the infuser into the cap first the grounds will float out. Twist cap close- Swirl the pitcher and let it sit for 12-36 hours. This makes a cold brew concentrate the longer you let it sit with the grounds in it. So be sure to add water to taste to the concentrate when you go to drink. Unless you like super strong brew.* the pitcher was too tall to fit in my main fridge standing, but fits PERFECT on my door. It would also fit on its side and the the cap does not leak at all.
title: Absolutely Awesome

author: Jamie M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2018
review_content: I love this coffee maker - you can make either hot or cold coffee.  It requires no electricity as it "steeps" self contained in the coffee pitcher.  I love iced coffee but do not like all the hassle of a traditional plug-in-socket coffee maker and this product is so quick and convenient - very little forethought required apart from preparing 12 hours before desired drink.  The coffee grounds literally sit inside the "pitcher filter" like a tea bag but for coffee grounds.  The iced coffee can stay in the refrigerator for as long as two weeks before turning rancid and bitter tasting - hallmarks of coffee that goes bad.There is an ice tea equivalent too, but it is not recommended by the manufacturer to substitute one pitcher for the other.  Something about different plastic materials  absorbing repugnant smells from what I read...I recently purchased another coffee pitcher for my cousin for Christmas.  She has a "Keurug" now but likes iced coffee.  I assumed it would be hard to make iced coffee with a hot coffee "Keurug" so this looked like the perfect solution as it is all self contained and can be used with little prep time besides putting the coffee grounds in the "pitcher filter" and placing in the refrigerator in advance for 12 hours to "steep" before drinking refreshing iced coffee.  For stronger coffee, you can "steep" as long as 24 hours before the coffee grounds become repugnant from what I gather.  In addition, I learned since my cousin is now a big outdoor enthusiast, camper type, that this is perfect for hot coffee during camping trips as no electricity is required and it tastes better than instant coffee hands down.  She has not used yet...since its winter...but she was excited.I use mine and love it.  Perfect gift for any coffee lover; and furthermore, great gift idea in a pinch.  If giving as a gift don't forget the coffee - an extra thoughtful touch.
title: Perfect hot coffee for camping, beats instant coffee

author: Chynna Blue
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2021
review_content: I love how easy this is to use and clean. I don’t buy things that can’t go in the dishwasher. author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review_content: Hello - I got this last covid season because I climbed aboard the iced coffee train, and let's be honest not everything was open all the time. I needed my fix! I like to give it a little shake before a pour it into my cup. I reuse a Starbucks Trenta cup. I fill with ice, then pour in coffee, a few pumps of Sugar-free vanilla, and some heavy cream and I am set.  You need to play around with different coffees to find the right flavor. This makes me happy and saves me $4-6 per drink.

author: ParaBellum
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2020
review_content: Great cold brewed coffee pitcher. I use 12 (measured) tablespoons and my coffee comes out perfect. I’ll cold brew anywhere from 24 to 72 hours depending on whether I really want strong coffee (I use BRCC dark roast coffee - Murdered Out, Blackbeard’s Delight, and Freedom Fuel but between the three prefer Freedom Fuel). Also make sure to use coarse/medium grind otherwise if you use anything finer you’ll get coffee grounds in the brew.Lastly, I also have the two quart iced tea pitcher and the mesh for that filter is not as fine so ideally could use the coffee pitcher for both coffee and iced teas. Clean up is easy - we use the OXO brush with the stainless steel handle (brush is not as harsh and won’t damage the filter element).

author: Rose Weets

review_content: This cold brew coffee pitcher has completely changed my coffee game. I am obsessed! author: J-M-L
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2018
review_content: To Make good cold brew, you need to have a high enough ratio of coffee beans to water to make the brew taste right. The Takeya doesn't allow enough beans to be used to do that. author: Buzzing B

author: Kelsey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2021
review_content: After about 2 months of using this as my daily coffee maker, I feel I have now found the ultimate recipe to success. Heed my warning, it is a lot of work. But it makes the best cup of iced coffee I've ever had - & depending on where you live, that might be highly necessary. See the below:-Start making it the night before the day before you want the coffee. If you want it Monday, start Saturday night. 36 hours is the key - I've tried 24 and I've tried 48, they were either too weak or too bitter (respectively). Usually, when I have one day's serving left I put it in a mason jar so I never have to go a day without.-Scoop 22 tablespoons of full beans (I do not know the measurement once its ground). Sounds like a lot, but if you buy a 2-tablespoon scooper it's not bad. I buy the Costco whole beans with the cat on them - lasts about a month for ~$15.-BUY A GOOD COFFEE GRINDER. I used to do this with a small, hand-controlled one (estimating what was considered "coarse") and it was terrible. I think after the second time I gave up & bought a conical burr coffee grinder (I set it to a coarseness level of 13/15). Best money I've spent for this, makes all the difference. The actual pitcher is pretty cheap, so it's easy to justify the extra cost.-Fill up the pitcher higher than 3/4. Figure out with a sharpie where the max you can fill it up without it overflowing is. Otherwise, you're just wasting beans. If it's accessible to you, filtered water will always be better than tap.-Put the grounds in the mesh, screw it all together, and put it in the fridge SIDEWAYS. Then, shake it every few hours (no set formula there - just whenever you remember. Maybe every 4-6 hours, except for the overnight).-Once your 36 hours is up, unscrew the top and hold the mesh filter slightly above the pitcher. Press GENTLY to release about 6oz or so more of cold brew that gets stuck in there (we do not waste in this house).-DO NOT PUT THE WHOLE THING OF GROUNDS IN YOUR GARBAGE DISPOSAL. You are welcome. After that, it's pretty easy to clean!BAM. It was a mission but you're done. This usually lasts me 3 days (& after the second day, put remainder in a mason jar & set it all back up). It's a lot of work, but I find it worth it. It's all about what you consider best for you! Just don't want you to spend $20+ for a piece of plastic that ends up in a landfill because it's not your thing.
